I think this article is conflating two issues which it is important to acknowledge are orthogonal:
* forcing journalists to use AI - LLMs replacing labor/quality
* whether or not journalistic publishers should partner with LLM inference providers - LLMs replacing *search*

* Many papers deserve more time than I give. If they get my attention repeatedly, I'll read more deeply each time

* ML research culture facilitates incremental progress
* Visual communication in our field has matured a lot

posts.text: My trick is that I've learned how to skim extremely effectively. I usually just read the middle 2-3 sentences of the abstract, figure 2 and its caption, and that's it. I've been tracking my reading habits for several months: it's rare that I give a paper two full minutes of attention.

reply_context.text:
Wait until you get older & fall into the "I'm tired. I'll read this later if at all." phase.

Happens to all us former voracious readers

posts.text: If you embed yourself in a thriving interest community, it's permissible to not be on top of research developments. You'll miss the news when it breaks, but if it had significant impact it'll continue to echo around the community and hearing about it eventually will be basically unavoidable.
As long as you're hanging out with people who do that stuff and talk about it, you'll be fine. Worst case: news of important research developments will be lagged but you'll still hear it.
